Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 08:46PM EmilyInOntario wrote: Hi Lori...I sure know how you feel. I'm trying out many suggestions and ideas I have found elsewhere on this board and from friends to make this feeling go away. I'm increasing my fluids to flush out the chemo and dead cancer cells, and have found a few foods that really feel good in my stomach ie soup, crackers, applesauce, ice water. I don't feel like doing much , which I hate, but resting alot and chatting with friends online, watching a few movies etc. I'm hoping someone will join us and tell us this goes away soon. I just don't have the concetration to read too many long threads right now to find all the answers.

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 10:24PM EmilyInOntario wrote: Day 24 of 33 for me. I have one more regular and 8 boosts. My skin is fairly dark pink and getting tender but haven't used any cream since the start ( was told not to) until tonight. They told me I could use glaxal base if it really started bothering me. I was told I could also use a cool but not cold wet cloth on the areas to relieve any discomfort. The skin where I will be getting the boosts is not as pink and the doctor felt I should tolerate the boosts okay. Was also told to keep the areas covered when in the sun ie clavicle area, armpit and any exposed chest and not to use sunscreen because of the chemicals in it .
Posts.Title: JUNE 2011 RADS bluewillowskys duckyb1

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2011 02:09PM EmilyInOntario wrote: Melanie...I saw the Lymphedema Physio some weeks back while still on chemo and she gave me some exercises and a temporary tensor sleeve. Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 04:37PM EmilyInOntario wrote: Hi all...saw my Rads doc today and asked about creams and lotions. He said they used to do that protocol but now they don't use anything at all unless there is evidence of a problem with the skin starting...so I guess this early in treatment they are not worried? I have had 8 treatments and no redness yet. About the green tea above...I was told not to take any extra anti oxidants or supplements during chemo or rads so maybe green tea is considered an anti oxidant?
Posts.Title: JUNE 2011 RADS bluewillowskys duckyb1

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2011 12:04PM EmilyInOntario wrote: If it's any help to anyone else...I count the seconds it takes to do each "beam"..I have 5 rad " beams" and it helps me get through the discomfort of having my arms above my head. It seems to take about 5 minutes to get me in the proper position and then only a few minutes of actual radiation. I also know that after the last beam I have to wait about 30 to 40 seconds for the techs to come back in the room and tell me I can put my arms down. *L* That's the part I look forward too.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 02:43PM EmilyInOntario wrote: I'm starting my radiation Monday June 13..next week...anyone else starting that day? I also found the simulation quick and not too stressful at all. Most of the time was spent getting the head and arm mold just right..I wasn't leaving there until I was totally comfortable as I knew I'd have to have my arms in position for 15 or more minutes esach treatment. My hands were numb by the end but it was only mildly uncomfortable and I have been practising  stretching my arms and shoulder muscles so muscles won't pull during treatment.The tattooing was just several mild pin pricks and I was talking through it all so hardly noticed.
Posts.Title: JUNE 2011 RADS bluewillowskys duckyb1

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2011 07:49PM EmilyInOntario wrote:  Hi all..just catching up..today was treatment #6 for me. No pink yet but was warned since I am so fair I would probably burn. However, I wasn't told to use any creams yet..but it sounds like most of you have been using creams or lotions from the start? Regarding the lymphedema..my hand started swelling a week or so BEFORE rads..and my surgery was back in November so can't blame the rads I guess. Regarding holding the breath...I was supposed to practise holding for a minute but couldn't make it past 30 seconds so was told not to worry about it and don't do that for treatments. I do have a mold they made for my arms but of course it was done in the CT scan room and now that I am in the rads room the rads machine is right against it. The mold really doesn't fit comfortably. As an added challenge my legs are still very weak from the taxotere ( 5 weeks ago) and I use a cane for short distances but need a wheelchair to get through the hospital to the rads department. This all makes the experience more of challenge but so far I'll still take this over chemo any day.
Posts.Title: JUNE 2011 RADS bluewillowskys duckyb1

Posts.Content: May 31, 2011 10:23AM EmilyInOntario wrote: Hi Ladies...may I join you? I had my radiation simulation , tattoing and the head and arm mold done yesterday and will be starting radiation mid June. I think I am doing 6 weeks of treatment, still trying to absorb all the information. Nothing was said to me about creams and lotions yet either. I was told that the new thing they are trying is having the patient hold their breath for up to a minute to raise the chest wall away from the heart and lungs to distance the radiation from those organs.(depending on how close they are from the CT scan results) Have any of you heard of this? I can't hold my breath that long so I guess they will have to do mine the way they have always done..

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 04:34PM EmilyInOntario wrote: JulieH...I had a MUGA scan day 4 of round 1 of chemo so I wasn't feeling too great that day..however what I recall was having blood drawn about 30 to 40 minutes ahead which they mix with a dye in the lab and then reinject it into you for the scan. Basically you just lie there as you would for any other scan and I think they did two 10 minute segments on me..of course you can't move until the scan is done. Overall it wasn't too bad and it was NOT clastrophobic like the MRI scans are.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 05:02PM EmilyInOntario wrote: FEC-D Start: Jan 28/2011 Cycle 1/6 Day 15 Has anyone had tooth issues while on chemo? I just spent 3 hours in our emergency department this afternoon with a horrible toothache. Started with tooth sensitivity a few days ago to hot and cold and then got bad today.Now on antibiotics but wondering what kind of dental work can actually be done while on chemo? I wore a mask in emerg...and after sitting for half an hour amongst the crowd of sickies I was finally placed in a special room away from the rest of the people waiting because I was on chemo. Then I was taken to the "inner sanctum" lounge to wait to be seen by the doctor...again sitting with people and their small children who were sick. Three hours later I was seen and given a prescription for antibiotics. I wondered what was the point in the special room if no other measures were going to be taken. The tooth pain made me think that maybe chemo wasn't so bad.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 09:43AM - edited Feb 11, 2011 11:11AM by EmilyInOntario  I admire all of you who are still working through all this! This is just a suggestion but maybe there are others here too who are struggling with "chemo fog brain". Would it be helpful if everyone started each post with Chemo start date and which round of chemo they are at and which day of the round they are at as well as which treatment? I am : FEC-D, Start date: Jan 28/2011 Cycle 1/6, Day 14 I have been trying to follow along with each of you to keep track of how you are all doing and where you are at but I confess my concentration is so poor I have become lost. But maybe it's just me. Heartburn: I had heartburn from hell and constant burning belching by day 4 and the doctor order rabeprazole and the relief has been marvelous. Mouth sores: I sipped ice water through my chemo RX and haven't had mouth sores yet, just very sensitive mouth. I was told to brush 4 times a day ( no flossing) and rinse with salt water 4 times a day. Also I always have a drink to sip  by me and suck hard candy so my mouth never becomes dry. I also use biotene. A few morning I have woke up with a burning tongue which was relieved as soon as I got fluids into me. I have had a mildly sore throat occasionally first thing in the am too which went away after fluids.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 12:22PM - edited Feb 13, 2011 01:41PM by EmilyInOntario  FEC-D Start: Jan 28/2011 Cycle 1/6 Day 16 Now I am wondering about the tooth pain I had yesterday. The doctor who looked at it yesterday in emerg said the gum was reddened around the tooth, however the pain continued in waves...got really bad so I was clutching my face and couldn't talk for about 5 minutes and then went away. This happened numerous times. Then the pain started in the roof of my mouth. It too came in waves, so painful that again I could only hold my face and close my eyes and get through the wave of pain. That happened several times and I tried coating my mouth with milk of mag to try to ease the pain. ( read that somewhere). I can detect no specific sore spots. This is the most bizarre thing I have even gone through. I presume this is mucosititis. Today so far no pain but ready to run to the drug store for whatever I can find if it starts again. Have been really diligent about brushing and rinsing with salt water and using biotene.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 01:13PM - edited Feb 18, 2011 01:16PM by EmilyInOntario FEC-D Start: Jan 28/2011 Cycle2/6 Day 1 Home from chemo this morning and starting to feel that "awful chemo feeling" already. Belching like crazyfrom upset stomach. I wanted to share my story about scans and mets. I was told I had bone mets in December as a radiologist was 98% sure that's what he saw on the CT scan. I was then put on Tamoxifen but as I had always had back problems I asked for second opinions and was sent for a MRI. Those results said mets in different places than the CT scan and none where the original radiologist saw them. I then had a bone biopsy. It was NEGATIVE for cancer. My advice to any of you is to push for second and even third opinions and have every test and scan you can if you are told you have bone mets. Ultimately a bone biopsy which does not hurt is what you want to have. I spent agonizing weeks trying to accept I was Stage 4 which is a very different prognosis as I am sure you are all aware. I now am back in Stage 3 and glad to be there. Really chemo fogged today so hope this makes sense... Tamoxifen was so much kinder than chemo but we do what we have to do right?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 06:15PM EmilyInOntario wrote: JulieH...is there any way you can take some days off during your chemo? Being exhausted will definitely make dealing with chemo so much harder for you.This stuff takes everything out of you mentally and physically and though some may have less side effects than others, those of us who do get the "worst" of the effects really need to do everything we can to get enough rest. I think being exhausted will definitely affect your appetite too and slow down how fast you bounce back to normal. Please do what you can to take care of yourself..*hug*

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2011 04:40PM EmilyInOntario wrote: For those of you who love your coffee but after chemo are now finding coffee and it's after taste are beyond disgusting, I have found Folgers Hazelnut Coffee ( Walmart) does NOT leave that " cow patty in the mouth " experience after a few sips.. I love my coffee and this has helped me considerably. Cream and sugar neutralizes it so it's not harsh on the sensitive chemo mouth. Hot chocolate made with milk seems to be palatable as well. Hope this idea helps someone.
Posts.Title: More Tips (and a Shopping List) for Getting Through Chemo rock MinusTwo

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 02:58PM EmilyInOntario wrote: I had mine just an hour or two before surgery. I did have some local freezing before the dye was injected and it hurt for 5 seconds..they told me to count ..and then it was done. Be prepared for the doctor to be wearing windsheild sized goggles and other protective gear. The doctor said she had to wear all the gear in case the patient jumped and the dye splashed or something. That was so NOT reassuring. But 5 seconds of pain wasn't so bad. The worst part for me was actually having to have my arm raised for the scan thing they did after for 10 minutes and told not to move.
